column4: Is there any reason why i wouldn't be able to access the files on partitions ubuntu mounts in /media? I can see them all but i can't manipulate them at all. I need unrestricted access
what filesystem?
change the permissions
using chown and/or chmod
if you want unrestricted access: chmod 777 /media/foo
thanks
np, you'll probably need to use sudo too
sorry to bother you again, but that command doesn't work even with sudo. I get a lock icon on all files, but when i have nautilus open with sudo i can access them. apparently it's already 777
well that command only gives you access to the main folder
is there a command to set all files and fiolders underneath that?
yes, but you generally don't want everything to have 777 permissions.  For example, a text file shouldn't be readable
I am going to eat, there is something you can do using ``find'' to change only directories and only files.  Someone else can probably show you how.  I'll be back in about 10 minutes
do you have more than one user that needs to access the drive?  it may be easier to just chown everything
it's a media server, so i need everyone to be able to read it

ok here, this will affect all the directories (remember, you must cd /media/foo first).  find . -type d -exec sudo chmod 777 '{}' \;             you may want to change the chmod to echo first just so you make sure it works right
thanks, and thanks for your patience too :)

we have to do files next, that would be 'find . -type f -exec sudo chmod 666 '{}' \;              that would give everyone read and write permissions to all the files.  If you want them to just be able to read them, you would use 444
ignore the initial ' before find
that's excellent, i'll give that a go
please remember to cd to the right directory first or you will screw stuff up :)
don't worry, i will
